Welcome to How To Cook That 
I am Ann Reardon and
today we are going to make chocolate feathers.  To do this firstly feel if your bench is cold, if it is you are going to need to
put something on it first to make sure your chocolate doesn't set too quickly
I'm using a silpat but you can use a book or a wad of paper.

Anything that's gonna insulate it from the
coldness of the bench.
Next take a sheet of non-stick paper
And you are going to need some white chocolate in a ziplock bag.
Push your chocolate to one corner, twist the bag and cut off the top.
and then pipe lines onto your non-stick baking paper.
Now you need to use either tempered chocolate of fake chocolate.  If you are not sure what I
mean by that then click on show more int eh description below this video
and click on chocolate tutorials and that will take you to the video playlist for chocolate.
There is one there on how to temper chocoalte and another on what chocoalte to use
for chocolate decorations.
if you want your feathers bent over then make sure you pipe
your line bent.

place the other sheet of baking paper
over the top and using your thumb or

finger gently push it out into shape
Now it helps if you have a picture of the

feather that you want to make in front of
you so that you can make sure it's the right shape.
Peel off the top sheet of your baking paper and put that to one side.
If you want to make a pointy end feather use a knife to sharpen one
end of it.
Then take a wooden skewer and draw chunks that you want to actually cut out of the feather
Then mess up the base of the feather where it si fluffy by pushing the skewer in and out.
Then very lightly scratch the surface of the feather
To get that textured look.
So again, draw the chunks that you want missing, fluff up the base and then scratch the
surface.
Take you bag of white chocolate and pipe a line down the feathers, keeping in mind

that on a feather that's often offset
slightly to one side.  Again that's where

having a photo of what you're wanting to make
will help you make it more realistic. If
you want to you can then add extra whisps of chocolate around the base section.
by now the top sheet that you peel off that chocolate is going to be set.
But you can still use it to make feathers.  Just turn your skewer over and use the blunt end
to scratch the texture into the surface.

and then pipe down the middle like you did
before

if you want chunks out of them then you have to
use the pointy end to scratch away
some of the chocolate.
Once they are set let them firm up in the fridge.
To colour them you can either colour your chocolate before you start using oil based colors.
You need to use oil based otherwise the water in the liquid colors will cause it to seize up.
or
you can use powdered colours like I am going to show you here.
so you can use a mixture of colors
because often feathers are more than one colour.  If you want that shine to them then
add some lustre dust
which you can buy at cake decorating stores.
Then you can use them to garnish your cake or your dessert.
Thanks for watching
and clicking like and share.
I really appreciate all of your support and all of you who have subscribed.
There is a new video out every week so if you haven't already subscribed make sure you do so.
